Hongkong Jan. 5, 1938
I have ust bought myself a Christmas present in the
form of a baby portable type writer which has standard key-
board but weighs only eight pounds and fits in a brief case.
What Hoboken is for the stage - you are for this gadget.
There have been many changes in the whole chinese sit-
uation as you can well imagine.
Our business was at first en-
tirely disrupted and the future looked decidedly dark.
have been able to work out a "new deal" and things are coming
our way very nicely.
The Minister of Communications who was
especially hostile to us has been dismissed and in his place
there 1s a new man wno 1s culte Irienaly ana cooperative.
appears also as though there will shortly be a change in the
Managing Director of CNAC and that here again we shall get &
much better man than we are now trying to work with.
CNAC is now operating between Chungking - Hankow and
Hongkong with DC-2s like the plane you flew in to Peiping
and we have iust received some large new flying boats which
will be used on the langstze between hankow and chungking.
there is a great dear of travel on the upper river now because
the chinese governmental activities have all been moved to
Chungkingâ€¢
Bond will remain in China in charge of CNAC operations
with headquarters in Hongkong and if there is any China left
after this war is over we should go right along as in the past
with our status more satisfactory than before the trouble start-
ed.
Kitsie is in Washington but will shortly leave to join her
nusband nere.
I expect to return to Manila and Baguio by the hext
Clipper which will also carry this letter.
Debby thinks that
perhaps you may have saved copies of some of my "family letters"
written before you came out to China.
If you have any of these
will you please
send them to me by airmail.
Only the ones you
received prior to your own departure for the Orient.
There
probably only a fee such letters but I did not
save copies and
will be very grateful if you can locate them either in your own
files or possibly some member of the Bixby family may have
a 1ew
put away somewhere.
I think copies were sent to artnur hoskins
and there was one
letter on military avaiation which I sent to
Phil Love with no copies to the family which I would also
like
to have.
Perhaps you could call Phil
(his initials are P.R.)
and ask him if he can dig up that letter from his files.
I personally feel
that the war has not gone
too badly
for the Chinese and that her only chance from the start was to
make the war so costly
for the Japanese as to bring about a rev-
olution in Japan.
If
the Japs had simply taken North China anc
most of the sea ports,
dug themselves in and then waited
Ior the
Chinese to drive
them out,
the latter would have had to
attack
a form of warfare with which
they are not familiar
under con-
ditions wholly favorable to the
Japanese.
Now however
une caps
have followed the
Chinese into the interior where it is almost
impossible to maintain their service of supply,
communications
are difficult and long lines must be defended against guerilla
attack - a form of warfare with which the Chinese are familiar
and decidedly potent.
If the Chinese morale will
lust hold out
for another
six months or so you may be surprisea at the
tinal
outcome
of the present hostilities.
Please do not go to too much trouble about the letters
but I will be very grateful if you can round
un a lew and seno
them
to me by airmail
to Baguio where I hope
t.o
remein
for the
next few weeks after you receive
this
letter
Lots of love
best of ioss for
1938 and many more years
to come
